title: Pathlaag
text:
Pathlaag () is a 1964 Indian <a href="Marathi%20language">Marathi</a>-language <a href="thriller%20film">thriller film</a> produced and directed by <a href="Raja%20Paranjape">Raja Paranjape</a>. It is an adaptation of the novel "Asha Parat Yete" () written by Jayant Deokule. The film stars <a href="Kashinath%20Ghanekar">Kashinath Ghanekar</a> and Bhavana. It was a commercial success, and won the <a href="National%20Film%20Award%20for%20Best%20Feature%20Film%20in%20Marathi">National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Marathi</a>. The film was later remade in <a href="Tamil%20language">Tamil</a> as "<a href="Idhaya%20Kamalam">Idhaya Kamalam</a>" (1965) and in <a href="Hindi">Hindi</a> as "<a href="Mera%20Saaya">Mera Saaya</a>" (1966).
Plot.
When Balasaheb Panse, a renowned Indian lawyer goes abroad, he receives a telegram informing him of the sudden death of his wife Asha. After she has been cremated and he is still in mourning, a woman arrested as a member of a criminal gang by the police claims to be Asha. She keeps telling Panse intimate details about their lives, expresses surprise that anyone could have thought her dead and implores him to have her released, causing a major emotional dilemma for Panse. Eventually, the second woman is revealed as indeed his wife, while the woman who died was her hitherto unmentioned twin sister.
Production.
"Pathlaag" is based on Jayant Deokule's novel "Asha Parat Yete". It was produced and directed by <a href="Raja%20Paranjape">Raja Paranjape</a> under Shripad Chitra, and the screenplay was written by <a href="Gajanan%20Digambar%20Madgulkar">G. D. Madgulkar</a>. The cinematography was handled by Datta Gorle. <a href="Kashinath%20Ghanekar">Kashinath Ghanekar</a> and Bhavana made their acting debuts with this film.
Soundtrack.
The music was composed by <a href="Datta%20Davjekar">Datta Davjekar</a>, and screenwriter Madgulkar also served as lyricist. There are only two songs in the film: "Ya Dolyanchi Don Pakhare" and "Nako Marus Hak", both sung by <a href="Asha%20Bhosle">Asha Bhosle</a>. The former attained popularity.
Release and reception.
"Pathlaag" became a commercial success, and won the <a href="National%20Film%20Award%20for%20Best%20Feature%20Film%20in%20Marathi">National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Marathi</a>. The film was later remade in <a href="Tamil%20language">Tamil</a> as "<a href="Idhaya%20Kamalam">Idhaya Kamalam</a>" (1965) and in <a href="Hindi">Hindi</a> as "<a href="Mera%20Saaya">Mera Saaya</a>" (1966). Despite its success, "Pathlaag" failed to set a trend of more detective films being made in <a href="Marathi%20cinema">Marathi</a>.
